byline.contributor: Lacey Russell reported from Senatobia, and Alan Blinder from Atlanta. Jack Begg contributed research from New York.
byline.original: By LACEY RUSSELL and ALAN BLINDER

abstract: At least three people who clapped and cheered from the audience during high school graduation in Senatobia, Miss, are charged with noise violations and disturbing the peace; face possibility of $500 fines and six-month jail sentences.
lead_paragraph: At least three people are facing the prospect of $500 fines and six-month jail terms after they were said to have yelled and clapped during a graduation ceremony in Mississippi.

headline.main: Authorities File Charges Over Loud Cheering at Mississippi High School Graduation
headline.print_headline: Supporters of Graduates Face Charges for Cheering

snippet: At least three people are facing the prospect of $500 fines and six-month jail terms after they were said to have yelled and clapped during a graduation ceremony in Mississippi.
